lAdfWquNVy8CHFOXs2pLsw.text: How cool to order your sushi the way and the ingredients that you like  Love the packing and the experience. I order my salmon sushi w all the goodies that I like. Salads are also very fresh and tasty. Highly recommended.

photos.caption: Photo of Maki-San - Singapore, Singapore. Cute design on the wall!

eFhgEHfbU8LumasAEv1r7Q.text: I really enjoy the maki rolls from this place because there are quirky references to "the sushi roll" everywhere plus the ingredients are fresh and healthy (depending on what you select to go in it, of course). I mean how many places will offer to stuff your maki with items like dried cranberries, sunflower seeds, crunchy jellyfish, honey soy chicken and Yuzu Honey Vinaigrette? Hey, I think I just created a roll, albeit not one I would suggest though. See how simple that was to order a customized roll? Can't decide or in a hurry? Just pick one of their House Sushi's that they've already created for the indecisive customers. I just wished they didn't have to put each roll into those fancy boxes, especially if you're going to eat-in.Seems like such a waste. For those with nut allergies ... Beware: "Our food is prepared at a facility that uses NUT ingredients." So roll yourself outta bed and go get some!

photos.caption: Photo of Maki-San - Singapore, Singapore. Clean up yo mess

a7k0el8bLuIWTWSgSViLzg.text: As Halloween is coming, the outlet has come out with a new limited edition flavour of sushi roll  known as The Black Magic Roll. It costs $8.90 a roll and only available at the Cathay outlet, via mobile application and online ordering.The sushi roll is stuffed with roasted peppers, kani stick, shredded chicken, roasted pumpkin, deep fried soft shell crab and tomato based chilli sauce. The soft shell crab gives a crispy and crunchy texture, while the pumpkin gives it a sweet and buttery texture. Although the chilli sauce looks a bit dark, it actually tastes not bad giving it a sweet taste with a hint of spicy. Together it gives a explosive combination in the mouth.So don't forget to try it. It is only available from now till end of this month.

photos.caption: Photo of Maki-San - Singapore, Singapore. The Black Magic Roll

ovlug57K-IC_Z5QkcFuYpA.text: I love this place with a passion. Customizable sushi in beautiful packaging reminiscent of Bankaku-style boxes - what isn't there to love?Located at the foot of The Cathay, I would sneakily suggest you buy a roll and bring it to the cinema if you have the munchies. I especially love brown rice in my sushi, and this is the place to get it. I won't go into detail about what works when it comes to maki rolls, because everybody has differing tastes, and what works for me may suck for you.What I want to talk about is the speed of rolling makis. The team is inconsistent with their efficiency. Some days I get my maki super quick, some days I get it super slow. I always go about 6pm and they have the same number of staff each time I go, so I assume this is a business processes issue. Maybe they'll improve on the speed in future - this is fast food after all.P.S. They don't take credit cards. Cash is king here!

hn5645HSwV42vlmUiVeWJg.text: i'm lovin' itYes, I realize this is the slogan of a certain fast food chain but it describes perfectly my thoughts about Maki-san. It came with high expectations (both Yelpers as non-Yelpers recommended this place) and was a bit afraid that it would be a let down but this concept is just plain awesomeness.Is it the best sushi I ever had? Nope* but they offers good quality sushi at a decent price and the concept is fantastic. As previous reviews described, this is Sushi meets Subway and coincidently I love sushi and I am a subway fan so this restaurant was right up my alley.I am a big fan of the possibility to customize your dishes (yes I am THAT person who takes longer to order a starbucks drink than to drink it) and I am always having a hard time picking sushi as I always end up thinking: "this roll has xyz that I love but I wish it came with abc which comes in this other roll...". Maki-san solves that problem by letting you design your own roll. For eternal doubters as myself it is still a chore as it creates even more choices but it gives you a strange sense of empowerment.I went for the combo which included a mega-san, a canned drink and a snack which came in under 13 S$. My roll was super tasty (maybe because it hit all the right spots since I could pick my own ingredients ) and the snack I chose was super delicious! I would have never expected that crab stick tempura would be something I would rave about but the dough was super light & fluffy and the cheese dip which I picked for it made it a match in haven.Although I have rated it the full five stars I do have some minor points of criticism:1) it is filled with teenagers which made me feel out but a) this is not maki-sans fault; b) it might be due to the time of the day and location (film theatre on a Saturday late afternoon) and c) I might just having to accept that I am getting older...2) I like to drink a lot with my food, in the meantime I have accepted that in Singapore there is seldom a bottomless soda but since there is quite a queue it is difficult to purchase an extra drink if you want a refill so a soda fountain /a water dispenser would be welcome, or even a way to purchase another drink without having to queue in the food queue.Overall this place is amazing. I was going to start a petition: "I want Maki-San at Holland V" but I figured it would lead me to go there more than once a week  and not eat anything else anymore so I am happy for now since the Cathay is not too far away either.* in case you are wondering what for me the best sushi is: without a doubt I would pick a place in Japan. No competition possible, sushi is just so much better there.

RhqmZm4vXvt3RYMKQ6Eo8w.text: Came here on a sunday at 1130am just as they were pulling up the shutters. The biggest selling point about maki san is that you get to make your own maki.. something like subway, except with sushi-ingredients.I went with the little-san $7.90, you get to pick 1 wrap (seaweed or healthy soy +$1)1 rice  (japanese white rice or healthy brown rice)3 essentials (avocado, steamed ebi, ebiko aka prawn roe)1 sprinkle (tempura crunch)1 house sauce (japanese caesar)And you get to watch them make them in front of you, which I think the staff was abit nervous and though he placed 5 prawns in the maki, admist his fluster whilst rolling up the maki, one shrimp fell out! *the horror*I enjoyed the maki. The tempura crunch was a good choice and it was very crispy instead. The prawn roe was rather fresh and the prawns were fresh and crunchy. The brown rice was also a nice healthy touch to the maki so I rarely see japanese maki with brown rice.All in all, a good choice for a quick lunch but a little-san to me, is still too big for me to finish on my own. The Mega-san is definitely big enough to share amongst two.

gWymsATkFhs6B0ZxTP_xDw.text: Love the packaging and the idea! First time trying it and got the egg crepe roll with brown rice Had Unagi, asparagus, ebi roe, avocado with miso sauce Healthy and fast!

photos.caption: Photo of Maki-San - Singapore, Singapore. Makisan

qBtKOYtB_B8gP_Unfbsucw.text: Pretty Japanese wrapping that won my heart! Not to mention, the food here is delicious, healthy, and customizable.Grab a clipboard and flyer and start creating your very own roll! You want brown rice? Check mark that! Salmon sashimi? Check mark that! Some wasabi mayo? Check mark that! It does take a while for the rolls to be made (they're fresh!) so spend some quality time Facebooking, Instagraming, and Yelping ;) Don't forget to claim your Perx! Before you know it, your beautiful roll will be ready for consumption in pretty Japanese wrapping! Check mark that Maki-San! Or rather, bookmark Maki-San now!

photos.caption: Photo of Maki-San - Singapore, Singapore. They need to add Yelp to that sign!

pY10lihQtHK1FfbvmFijgg.text: Think of Subway, or The Counter, but for sushi.For those of you that are sushi purists who enjoy tasting the unique flavors of various raw fish, this might not be the place for you.  However, if you want to experiment with delicious ingredients presented to you as a maki roll, this place is heaven on earth.I went with my roommate, and we split a seaweed white rice mega san roll (which came out to $9.90), which allows you to choose 5 essentials, 1 special, 1 "sprinkles," and 1 sauce.  If you get a little-san, you can choose 3 essentials, 1 "sprinkles" and 1 sauce--however, I recommend getting a mega-san, because only with that option can you get the yummier ingredients (salmon sashimi, tempura shrimp, fried soft-shell crab, grilled eel, etc.).  For the amount that you receive, $10 is a pretty decent price, especially given that sushi is never cheap and that the average roll at a sushi bar costs around $12.We chose boiled shrimp, egg omelette, Japanese cucumber, avocado, and tobikio (flying fish roe) as our essentials, grilled eel as our special, pine nuts for our sprinkles, and garlic aioli as our sauce.  It tasted amazing--the combination of all those ingredients was even more tasty than it was in my mind.  The fish was fresh and so were the other ingredients, and the sauce added the perfect touch without overwhelming the roll with flavor.  I highly recommend the combination we got.The restaurant also offers pre-set rolls too for the indecisive ones like me.  They sell snack items as well, and serve miso soup in a coffee cup!  But what really takes the cake is the cute box that the sushi is served in.  The only sad part of my experience is that garlic aioli got on the box, or else I would have really wanted to save the box as a keepsake.At the basement of the Cathay, it's not too hard to miss!  It's make-your-own-sushi, and I feel like any combination of ingredients would be tasty.  But then again, when is sushi not the best thing ever?

photos.caption: Photo of Maki-San - Singapore, Singapore. My mega-san in Maki-San's signature decorated boxes, served with miso soup in a coffee cup!

gFvNAvGtJV-TwNZevkUxOw.text: Every time I'm in Cathay, it always catches my eye. They have the cutest packaging--I would love to collect them all!And the food... The sushi was so good! And really worth it for the price! It's nice that it's customizable and there are a lot of options to choose from! Next time, I'm definitely trying the salad--because they look as goo as the sushi!

1D-Nr_cnyohlvPZwDho_Tg.text: Craving for good yet excellent sushi in town area? Look no further as this place serves both flavorful and budget friendly sushi.Located at the basement of the Cathay is this store (near to the escalator too). I've also seen a few people posting pictures of the sushis and the packaging box for the sushi. Decided to takeaway the Child's Play (House Sushi).As it was past lunch time, there were not a lot of people queueing. And as this is my first time stepping into a "customized sushi" store, I had no clue besides looking up at the head boards which specified the house special sushis, little or mega san sushis (different ingredients). After skimming through the menu of the house sushi, I decided to get the Child's Play as it sounds tasty.After ordering, you will receive a round-shaped thing with the order number on it while the "sushi masters" prepare the different sushis. While waiting, I realized that they have either seaweed wrap or healthy soy wrap and you could choose white rice or brown rice if you are to customized your sushis. There is a step-by-step form you can use to order the customized sushi which made it simpler for the "sushi masters". For the house sushi, they only come with a seaweed wrap and white rice with the ingredients listed according to its names.Consumed my sushi a couple of hours later. Even though the paper wrap inside the box was wet from the sushi itself, the sushi was still in perfect order (the box helped it not to spill the ingredients inside it). It was definitely flavorful and it has quite a number of ingredients which leave you with a tangy feeling of wanting more of it. It came in 6 pieces and the cut was a thick cut. The seaweed added flavor to the sushi itself. The packaging of the sushi was colorful and at the center of it, the logo of the store was clearly labelled too. For takeaway, they will provide a pair of wooden chopsticks, two packets of soy sauce and a packet of wasabi.Overall, it was definitely a good choice to try this place out. Will come back for more sushi soon :)

M_o1vq59m15tdg930V7q2w.text: Love the concept of customizable sushi rolls, and their Mega-San set meals are really affordable. Seats are very limited so we ordered takeout and sat by the fountain to eat instead.

4tPI7VQGFdUmgtMy2eWTxw.text: This place is like a Subway's for sushi-- customizeable, healthy and efficient.You can either choose a pre-set option, or customize your own sushi roll or salad.If you choose the latter, this is how it works:1. You pick up an ingredients list for either a sushi roll or salad2. You check off the appropriate ingredients you want (e.g. brown/white rice, seaweed,  tempura shrimp/smoked duck/salmon sashimi, caramelized japanese sweet potatoes/asparagus/corn/carrots, wasabi mayo/caesar dressing, etc.)3. You give your order to the cashier and pay the appropriate amount4. Cashier gives you a buzzer to let you know when your order is ready5. Pick up your order when your beeper buzzesI almost always choose a brown rice option with soft shell crab tempura, avocado, sunflower seeds and a few more things. The ingredients are all fresh and healthy and the service is very friendly.If you order the sushi roll, there's this robotic contraption that cuts the sushi-- which looks really nifty.It's decorated in colorful furniture that's clearly painted Ikea furniture and works really well with the simple, artsy style of the place.Relaxing atmosphere and good for grabbing a quick bite with friends.Not the cheapest of places, but sushi never is.Thumbs up

M0xh3VFZJ6BcqtdcqY8VcQ.text: There are two options, a salad or sushi roll, both of which are beautifully packaged and made to order. The ingrdients in my salad were fresh and crispy, but the temperature of the chicken teriyaki was colder than the salad itself. The miso dressing paired with corn, the lemon included in the egg wrap and cream cheese and salmon roll allow me to safely say that Maki-San is a Japanese fusion restaurant/cafe. The brightly colored walls, cartoon artwork, sensitive music, and sushi rolls wrapped like a present leads me  to my final conclusion, that this restaurant is designed for young girls. I spent 30 minutes in the cafe and all the customers were female, half were wearing school uniforms. The artwork depicting angry ingredients with the slogan, "if you don't like it, take it out!" Illustrates just how customizable the menu is for picky eaters or those with diet restrictions.
